title: Vibrational Spectroscopy of Structured Fluids Using Cryogenic STEM-EELS
content: Structured fluids, materials that contain multiple phases and display a complex array of flow behaviors, are abundant in our everyday lives and present a great and unexplored opportunity for characterization using electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) in scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) [1]. Developments in STEM-EELS over the last two decades include development of high-performance electron monochromators, improved spectrometer electron optics and introduction of new detectors with a high detector quantum efficiency (DQE) [2]. For example, using a STEM equipped with a thermally assisted field emission source enables EELS to be performed with an energy resolution (DE) in the range 0.5-0.8eV. Introduction of a commercially available monochromated instrument at the turn of the century enabled DE<0.2eV. [3]. While subsequent improvements in electronics and electron optics delivered incremental advances, it was the introduction of the a-design that revoultionized performance [4]. This design initially delivered DE in 10-20meV range, but improvements in electron optics and detectors have enabled <4 meV to be achieved [2]. This opens new opportunities for the study of vibrational excitations using STEM-EELS.
